course.subject: CHEM
course.name: Great Ideas in Chemistry
course.description: The course covers many major advances, historical developments and contemporary applications of critical concepts in Chemistry. These may range from atomic theory and identification and arrangement of the elements to modern problems such as CO2 and global warming; pollution and environmental clean-up. Unlike other Chemistry courses it will focus on the background to our knowledge, on what experimental evidence our current theories are based, and how old ones were overturned or modified. For science students in their third or fourth year of study under the four-year degree only. Other students with the prerequisites may seek instructor's approval for enrollment in the course.
course.prerequisites: Any CHEM course at or above 1000-level or CORE 1120

reviews.author: yo~
reviews.title: Very Good Grade Course
reviews.comment_content:
Mainly about the history of chemistry developments
Part 1: Atoms: the Foundation of Chemistry
Lecture 1. We are Stardust
Lecture 2. Origin of the Elements
Lecture 3. A Brief History of Science
Lecture 4. From Alchemy back to Atoms
Lecture 5. Discovering the Elements
Lecture 6. The Periodic Table

Part 2: Molecules: Bonding, Structures, Reactions
Lecture 7. Models of the Atom
Lecture 8. History of the Chemical Bond
Lecture 9. Structure: Molecular Shapes
Lecture 10. X-ray Crystallography
Lecture 11. Chemical Reactions
Lecture 12. Chemical Synthesis

Part 3: Chemistry in the Modern World
Lecture 13. Chemical Analysis: Elements and Isotopes
Lecture 14. Chemical Analysis Chromatography
Lecture 15. Chemical Analysis Spectroscopy
Lecture 16. Biological Chemistry
reviews.comment_teaching: As this is a blended learning course, most teaching relies on the videos he taped a few years ago. We also have a chance to visit his lab to learn more about the X-Ray Crystallographer. Still, I think his teaching is ok.
reviews.comment_grading:
30% Online Work and Quiz
20% In-class Discussion and Quiz
30% Mid-Term Test (Format similar to the lecture quizzes, mainly from Lecture 3-6, printed notes allowed)
20% Term Presentations (2-3 ppl, 15 mins with Q&A)
Prof. Williams gave half A-range and half B-range, so is very very good grade. So grading I would like to give an A+ for this course.
reviews.comment_workload: Although we gather every 4 lecture time slots, every time we gather will have a group assignment so we need to discuss the answers together after class and this is the main workload come from. Starting from week 5/7, the assignment becomes very hard and some questions require some knowledge in some 4000-level CHEM courses. Fortunately, the online quizzes and the mid term test is quite straightforward.

reviews.author: supermin
reviews.title: Interesting course, heavy workload
reviews.comment_content:
Explores the "back stories" of chemical discoveries and developments. Overall quite interesting if you're into learning untold chemistry facts.

Weeks 1-4. Atoms: the Foundation of Chemistry
Lecture 1. We are Stardust
Lecture 2. The Origin of the Elements
Lecture 3. A Brief History of Science
Lecture 4. From Alchemy back to Atoms
Lecture 5. Discovering the Elements
Lecture 6. The Periodic Table

Weeks 5-8 Molecules: Bonding, Structures, Reactions
Lecture 7. Models of the Atom
Lecture 8. History of the Chemical Bond
Lecture 9. Molecular Shapes
Lecture 10. X-ray Crystallography: Seeing is Believing !
Lecture 11. Transformation: Chemical Reactions
Lecture 12. Chemical Synthesis: Molecular Creations of Man

Week 9: Mid Term Review and Exam

Weeks 9-12 Chemistry in the Modern World
Lecture 13. Chemical Analysis: Elements and Isotopes
Lecture 14. Chemical Analysis : Separations
Lecture 15. Chemical Analysis : Molecular Spectroscopy
Lecture 16. Development of Biological Chemistry
Lecture 17. Better Living through Chemistry
Lecture 18. What is Life ? From Chemistry to Biology

Week 13: Presentations
reviews.comment_teaching:
Both Prof Chan and Prof Williams are very active and kind. They really want you to understand the impact of the discoveries and how they affect our lives.

Both are very supportive when you have questions regarding the course content and assignments.
reviews.comment_grading:
Eight Quizzes (for L1~L9, excluding L8): 20%
Overall mid-high scores

Eight In-Class Group Tasks: 20%
Overall high scores

One Midterm Exam (open-book): 30%
2nd highest

Group Presentation (poster layout, answering professors): 30%
Top score

Q/A session of Presentation
Full score

Final Grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
Class gathered every fourth class (so 1 class in two weeks), and a group task is given every time.

You need to listen to lecture videos yourself and do Canvas quizzes, some have deadlines.

Midterms is done in class, open book but quite a lot of questions with traps for careless mistakes.

Poster presentation is done (basically simpler version of Capstone Project poster). It's done during exam break!

There's something to do every week, so the load is quite high. Time management is required to get high grades.
